content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::AbstractString)
    questions = Regex(raw"^# Question\s*(.*)")
    answers   = Regex(raw"^# Answer\s*(.*)")
    
    questions_and_answers = findall(questions, md) âˆª findall(answers, md)
    
    q_a = Tuple{String, String}[]
    for (i, match) in enumerate(questions_and_answers)
        if match isa RegexMatch
            start = match.offset[1] + match.captures[1].length
            end_ = findnext(r"\n# ", md, match.offset[0] + 1) - 1
            q_a_text = strip(md[start:end_])
            if start > end_
                break
            end
            
            push!(q_a, (strip(q_a_text[1:findfirst("\n", q_a_text) - 1]),
                       strip(q_a_text[findlast("# Answer", q_a_text) + 6:end])))
        end
    end
    
    return q_a
end
```

This function uses regular expressions to find all instances of `# Question` and `# Answer` in the markdown text. It then strips leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text before returning a tuple of questions and answers.
